you could just create your own 'storage' Object/Command and system (instead of using the 'inventory'), it might be easier/better than trying to mess around with the built-in inventory system and/or creating your own inventory pane and etc. As this would give you the control you seek, whereas you don't have this control by default with the built-in quest inventory's system.

you'll probably have to use List Attributes, so if you don't already know how to, you'll need to learn their usage.

Posts.EditableText: Well, if I use the Second Inventory Pane Utility, I can just remove the original pane and set the replacement to RemoveSceneryObjects(ScopeInventory()), and that way the objects don't show up in the pane but are still interactable. I was hoping for a slightly cleaner solution, but this does the job, and does it well.
